factoid: Adjutant General Wolzogen said, "the war should be extended widely," when riding past Prince Andrew.
Bagratón detested Adjutant General Wolzogen.
Adjutant General Wolzogen rode up while General Kutúzov was at dinner.
Adjutant General Wolzogen had come from Barclay de Tolly to report on the progress of affairs on the left flank.
Barclay de Tolly was a sagacious officer.
Barclay de Tolly saw crowds of wounded men running back and the disordered rear of the army.
Barclay de Tolly weighed all circumstances and concluded that the battle was lost.
Barclay de Tolly sent his favorite officer to the commander in chief with the news that the battle was lost.
General Kutúzov was chewing a piece of roast chicken with difficulty and glanced at Adjutant General Wolzogen with brightening eyes.
Adjutant General Wolzogen stretched his legs nonchalantly and approached General Kutúzov with a half-contemptuous smile.
Adjutant General Wolzogen thought that "Der alte Herr" (German name for General Kutúzov) "is making himself very comfortable."

Adjutant General Wolzogen looked severely at the dishes in front of General Kutúzov and began to report to General Kutúzov the position of affairs on the left flank as Barclay de Tolly had ordered him to and as he himself had seen and understood it.

Adjutant General Wolzogen reported: "All the points of our position are in the enemy’s hands and we cannot dislodge them for lack of troops, the men are running away and it is impossible to stop them."
General Kutúzov ceased chewing and fixed an astonished gaze on Adjutant General Wolzogen, as if not understanding what was said to him.

Adjutant General Wolzogen noticed General Kutúzov’s agitation and said with a smile: "I have not considered it right to conceal from your Serene Highness what I have seen. The troops are in complete disorder."
General Kutúzov shouted: "You have seen? You have seen?"

General Kutúzov shouted: "How... how dare you!..." and made a threatening gesture with trembling arms, saying: "How dare you, sir, say that to me? You know nothing about it. Tell General Barclay from me that his information is incorrect and that the real course of the battle is better known to me, the commander in chief, than to him."
Adjutant General Wolzogen was about to make a rejoinder, but General Kutúzov interrupted him.

General Kutúzov said: "The enemy has been repulsed on the left and defeated on the right flank. If you have seen amiss, sir, do not allow yourself to say what you don’t know! Be so good as to ride to General Barclay and inform him of my firm intention to attack the enemy tomorrow."
All were silent, and the only sound audible was the heavy breathing of the panting old general.

General Kutúzov said: "They are repulsed everywhere, for which I thank God and our brave army! The enemy is beaten, and tomorrow we shall drive him from the sacred soil of Russia," crossing himself, and he suddenly sobbed as his eyes filled with tears.
Adjutant General Wolzogen shrugged his shoulders and curled his lips, stepped silently aside, marveling at General Kutúzov’s conceited stupidity.
General Kutúzov said: "Ah, here he is, my hero!" to a portly, handsome, dark-haired general who was just ascending the knoll.
The general that General Kutúzov addressed was Raévski.
Raévski had spent the whole day at the most important part of the field of Borodino.
Raévski reported that the troops were firmly holding their ground and that the French no longer ventured to attack.
After hearing Raévski, General Kutúzov said in French: "Then you do not think, like some others, that we must retreat?"
Raévski replied: "On the contrary, your Highness, in indecisive actions it is always the most stubborn who remain victors," and in his opinion...
General Kutúzov called to his adjutant: "Kaysárov!" and told him: "Sit down and write out the order of the day for tomorrow."
General Kutúzov told another officer: "Ride along the line and announce that tomorrow we attack."

While General Kutúzov was talking to Raévski and dictating the order of the day, Adjutant General Wolzogen returned from Barclay and said that General Barclay wished to have written confirmation of the order the field marshal had given.
